comment_text.mn55:1.2: Jīvaka was the Buddha’s doctor. His story is told in Kd 8, where we learn that he was abandoned on a trash heap by his mother Sālavatī, only to be discovered and raised by Prince Abhaya of Magadha, a Jain MN 58. He was called “Survivior” (jīvaka) and “Raised by a Prince” (komārabhacca). In later Ayurveda, kaumārabhṛtya means “paediatrics”, and a lost treatise on that subject is attributed to Jīvaka (Jīvakatantra).
comment_text.mn55:3.2: This was an accusation made against the Buddha by Jains (AN 8.12:31.2, Kd 6:31.13.1). They objected only to eating meat “killed on purpose for him”, and so by implication not all eating of meat. This is consistent with several Jain scriptural passages indicating that ascetics may, under certain strictures, eat meat (Ācaraṅgasūtra 2.1.10.5–6, Bhagavatīsūtra 557 (p. 1261a), Kalpasūtra (Sāmācārī 17), Dasaveyāliyasutta 5–1.73).
comment_text.mn55:5.2: The relevant Vinaya rule makes the meaning clear: “When you know it was killed on purpose for you” (Kd 6:31.14.4). To allay suspicion of improper meat, mendicants are also required to check the provenance of meat before eating (Kd 6:23.9.9).
comment_text.mn55:7.4: Reading taṁ … idaṁ as the accusative of relation, and me as instrumental, for which compare yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho at DN 13:12.1. The point of the passage is that he has merely heard that Brahmā abides in love, but he witnesses that the Buddha does so.
comment_text.mn55:7.6: Greed, hate, and delusion are the fundamental underlying defilements that give rise to “ill will”, the opposite of love.
comment_text.mn55:11.6: Just as ill will is the opposite of love, “cruelty” (vihesā), “discontent” (arati), and “repulsion” (paṭigha) are the respective opposites of compassion, rejoicing, and equanimity (MN 62:18.2 ff).
comment_text.mn55:13.6: This sutta marks the occasion of Jīvaka’s conversion. It would seem that he had previously harbored doubts due to his Jain upbringing. Elsewhere he appears as a devotee of the Buddha. AN 1.256:1.1 records that he was the foremost disciple with “confidence in a person”, establishing that he was a stream-enterer. The occasion of his stream-entry, however, is not recorded in Pali.

root_text.mn55:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane.
root_text.mn55:2.1: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn55:3.2: ‘samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ uddissa pāṇaṁ ārabhanti, taṁ samaṇo gotamo jānaṁ uddissakataṁ maṁsaṁ paribhuñjati paṭiccakamman’ti.
root_text.mn55:3.3: Ye te, bhante, evamāhaṁsu: ‘samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ uddissa pāṇaṁ ārabhanti, taṁ samaṇo gotamo jānaṁ uddissakataṁ maṁsaṁ paribhuñjati paṭiccakamman’ti, kacci te, bhante, bhagavato vuttavādino, na ca bhagavantaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgacchatī”ti?
root_text.mn55:4.1: “Ye te, jīvaka, evamāhaṁsu: ‘samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ uddissa pāṇaṁ ārabhanti, taṁ samaṇo gotamo jānaṁ uddissakataṁ maṁsaṁ paribhuñjati paṭiccakamman’ti na me te vuttavādino, abbhācikkhanti ca maṁ te asatā abhūtena.

root_text.mn55:6.1: Idha, jīvaka, bhikkhu aññataraṁ gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā upanissāya viharati.
root_text.mn55:6.2: So mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.mn55:6.3: Tamenaṁ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upasaṅkamitvā svātanāya bhattena nimanteti.
root_text.mn55:6.5: So tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena tassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamati; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdati.

root_text.mn55:12.1: “Yo kho, jīvaka, tathāgataṁ vā tathāgatasāvakaṁ vā uddissa pāṇaṁ ārabhati so pañcahi ṭhānehi bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati.
root_text.mn55:12.3: ‘gacchatha, amukaṁ nāma pāṇaṁ ānethā’ti, iminā paṭhamena ṭhānena bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati.
root_text.mn55:12.4: Yampi so pāṇo galappaveṭhakena ānīyamāno dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, iminā dutiyena ṭhānena bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati.
root_text.mn55:12.6: ‘gacchatha imaṁ pāṇaṁ ārabhathā’ti, iminā tatiyena ṭhānena bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati.
root_text.mn55:12.7: Yampi so pāṇo ārabhiyamāno dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, iminā catutthena ṭhānena bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati.
root_text.mn55:12.8: Yampi so tathāgataṁ vā tathāgatasāvakaṁ vā akappiyena āsādeti, iminā pañcamena ṭhānena bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati.
root_text.mn55:12.9: Yo kho, jīvaka, tathāgataṁ vā tathāgatasāvakaṁ vā uddissa pāṇaṁ ārabhati so imehi pañcahi ṭhānehi bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavatī”ti.
root_text.mn55:13.1: Evaṁ vutte, jīvako komārabhacco bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn55:13.3: Kappiyaṁ vata, bhante, bhikkhū āhāraṁ āhārenti;
root_text.mn55:13.4: anavajjaṁ vata, bhante, bhikkhū āhāraṁ āhārenti.
root_text.mn55:13.6: upāsakaṁ maṁ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.

translation_text.mn55:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca.
translation_text.mn55:2.1: Then Jīvaka went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn55:3.2: ‘They slaughter living creatures specially for the ascetic Gotama. The ascetic Gotama knowingly eats meat prepared on his behalf: this is a deed he caused.’
translation_text.mn55:3.3: I trust that those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and do not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?”
translation_text.mn55:4.1: “Jīvaka, those who say this do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false and untrue.
translation_text.mn55:5.1: In three cases I say that meat may not be eaten:
translation_text.mn55:5.3: These are three cases in which meat may not be eaten.
translation_text.mn55:5.4: In three cases I say that meat may be eaten:
translation_text.mn55:5.5: it’s not seen, heard, or suspected.
translation_text.mn55:5.6: These are three cases in which meat may be eaten.
translation_text.mn55:6.1: Take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
translation_text.mn55:6.2: They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn55:6.3: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.
translation_text.mn55:6.4: The mendicant accepts if they want.
translation_text.mn55:6.5: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.
translation_text.mn55:6.6: That householder or their child serves them with delicious almsfood.
translation_text.mn55:6.8: ‘It’s so good that this householder serves me with delicious almsfood!
translation_text.mn55:6.9: I hope they serve me with such delicious almsfood in the future!’
translation_text.mn55:6.11: They eat that almsfood untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
translation_text.mn55:6.13: At that time is that mendicant intending to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both?”
translation_text.mn55:6.15: “Aren’t they eating blameless food at that time?”
translation_text.mn55:7.4: Now, I’ve seen the Buddha with my own eyes,
translation_text.mn55:7.5: and it is the Buddha who truly abides in love.”
translation_text.mn55:7.6: “Any greed, hate, or delusion that might give rise to ill will has been given up by the Realized One, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and is unable to arise in the future.
translation_text.mn55:7.7: If that’s what you were referring to, I grant it.”
translation_text.mn55:7.8: “That’s exactly what I was referring to.”
translation_text.mn55:8-10.1: “Take the case, Jīvaka, of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.

translation_text.mn55:12.1: “Jīvaka, anyone who slaughters a living creature specially for the Realized One or the Realized One’s disciple brims with much wickedness for five reasons.
translation_text.mn55:12.3: ‘Go, fetch that living creature,’ this is the first reason.
translation_text.mn55:12.4: When that living creature experiences pain and sadness as it’s led along by a collar, this is the second reason.
translation_text.mn55:12.6: ‘Go, slaughter that living creature,’ this is the third reason.
translation_text.mn55:12.7: When that living creature experiences pain and sadness as it’s being slaughtered, this is the fourth reason.
translation_text.mn55:12.8: When they serve the Realized One or the Realized One’s disciple with unallowable food, this is the fifth reason.
translation_text.mn55:12.9: Anyone who slaughters a living creature specially for the Realized One or the Realized One’s disciple brims with much wickedness for five reasons.”
translation_text.mn55:13.1: When he had spoken, Jīvaka said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn55:13.3: The mendicants indeed eat allowable food.
translation_text.mn55:13.4: The mendicants indeed eat blameless food.
translation_text.mn55:13.6: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
